currentDoc:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the






Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Menstruation is less controversial a topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 






Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

I've never experienced period shaming, but have personally witnessed someone get her first period during a class, without knowing what it was.  Menstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school.

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school.

Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afra






Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available 






Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

I've never experienced period shaming, but have personally witnessed someone get her first period during a class, without knowing what it was. It was an embarrassinmemory that will Menstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

It was an embarrassing memory that will hurt stay with hMenstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

It was an traumatic memory that will hurt and stay with her for the reMenstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

I've never experienced period shaming, but have personally witnessed someone get her first period during a class, without knowing what it was, in a class of cruel aIt was an traumatic memory that will hurt and stay with her for the rest of her life. Menstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

I've never experienced period shaming, but have personally witnessed someone get her first period during a class, without knowing what it was, in a class of cruel children. It was an traumatic memory that will hurt and stay with her for the rest of her life. Menstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions, not to mention potential humilia

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy!

Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions, not to mention potential humiliation and judgement from uncaring peers. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy

I've never experienced period shaming, but have personally witnessed someone get her first period during a class, without knowing what it was, in a class of cruel children. It was an traumatic memory that will hurt and stay with her for the rest of her life. Menstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions, not to mention potential humiliation and judgement from uncaring peers. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy, mentally and physically.

Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions, not to mention potential humiliation and judgement from uncaring peers. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 
No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy, mentally and physically.

I've never experienced period shaming, but have personally witnessed someone get her first period during a class, without knowing what it was, in a class of cruel children. It was an traumatic memory that will hurt and stay with her for the rest of her life. 

Menstruation is less controversial a topic than most Sex Ed topic, and people from all walks of life can agree that it happens to girls during puberty, and requires ways to control it. Without proper help during periods, clothes can be damaged, and there can be unsanitary conditions, not to mention potential humiliation and judgement from uncaring peers. 

Pads and tampons are similar to toilet paper, soap and Band-Aids because they all serve a common purpose: they help clean and protect, to prevent illness and infection.  The parents should provide most basic healthcare items, but they also should be available from the school. 


No girl should ever need to have embarrassing stains or be afraid of her own body. It is the very least we can do to provide cheap and readily available tampons and pads in our schools. 


Our children are the future-they deserve to have the basic items they need to stay healthy, mentally and physically.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?
